qas.question: What are examples of classes of eukaryotes where genome only refers to the information found in chromosomes?
What is a name for the genetic material found within chloroplasts?
What is a name for the genetic makeup of mitochondria?
What are the eukaryotes found in the mitochondria called?
What does genome mean when referring to eukaryotes such as mitochondria?

plausible_answers.text: the genetic information contained by DNA within these organelles

qas.question: What is not considered as part of the plastome?
What do chloroplasts have that is referred to as the mitochondrial genome?

context: In eukaryotes such as <a0_0><b4_0>plants, protozoa and animals<b4_0/><a0_0/>, however, "genome" carries the typical connotation of <b5_0>only information on chromosomal DNA<b5_0/>. So although these organisms contain chloroplasts or mitochondria that have their own DNA, <b6_0>the genetic information contained by DNA within these organelles<b6_0/> is not considered part of the genome. In fact, mitochondria are sometimes said to have <b7_0>their own genome<b7_0/> often referred to as the "<a2_0>mitochondrial genome<a2_0/>". The DNA found within the chloroplast may be referred to as <b3_0>the "<a1_0>plastome<a1_0/>"<b3_0/>.
